content:
A new Argonaut project for 2021 is to provide guidance for supporting FHIR “write” use cases to an EHR. We have agreed to include the following Patient Generated Data categories as in scope use cases:

  • Vitals (e.g. : Weight, Blood Pressure)
  • Activity (e.g. Steps)
  • At home diagnostics (Blood Glucose, Covid 19 Test)
  • Sleep
  • Medications
  • PROS/Assessments

We would like feedback from the FHIR Implementer community for additional categories that we may have omitted.

Note that the Patient Empowerment Work Group is currently working on a Patient Corrections IG and things like Demographic Updates are out of scope.
for more information on this project see the Argo Write Homepage
Patient Empowerment is also working on a paper. I am sure they will very much prefer to put their attention on an IG.
Immunizations (not all immunizations are given in a medical setting, I received some in a business setting prior to a business trip to India)
how about uploaded documents (DocumentReference and/or Composition) -- as received from other health activities that are not otherwise connected
QuestionnaireResponse seems appropriate, though I think that's already supported?

Pain would come to mind as a specific category, oftentimes administered as a VAS with a result from 0..10, but the concept of a VAS is still hard to cleanly express as a FHIR Questionnaire. Symptom/pain location is another one I am seeing in paper questionnaires (circling on a stylised body image where you have the pain or the itch, or the wound). And photograph upload, e.g. of rashes, wounds, inflammations, etc.
photographs would mean DocumentReference, which could be useful to share a bunch of things - though it might overwhelm providers some.

The photograph piece is becoming more and more requested in "early discharge" and "hospital at home" scenarios. You discharge patients a few days earlier and let them document the progress of their healing through a camera. This has accelerated quite a bit due to the pandemic along with many other patient-facing virtual care use-cases. So the goal is not to let patients randomly send in pictures, but rather to agree with them that every day they would take a picture, take their temperature, and document symptoms and pain. This will then be looked at by nursing staff.
